title: LAYING DOWN YOUR LIFE FOR THE SHEEP Part 4
scripture_text:
I am the good shepherd. The good shepherd lays down his life for
the sheep. The hired hand is not the shepherd and does not own the
sheep. So when he sees the wolf coming, he abandons the sheep and runs
away.Then the wolf attacks the flock and scatters it. The man runs away
because he is a hired hand and cares nothing for the sheep. "I am the
good shepherd; know my sheep and my sheep know me---just as the Father
knows me and I know the Father---and I lay down my life for the sheep.
have other sheep that are not of this sheep pen. I must bring them
also. They too will listen to my voice, and there shall be one flock and
one shepherd The reason my Father loves me is that I lay down my
life---only to take it up again. No one takes it from me, but I lay
it down of my own accord. I have authority to lay it down and authority
to take it up again. This command I received from my Father.
devotional:
We have been thinking about how Jesus laid down his life for the
sheep. He did it because his sheep know him. Jesus said 'I know my sheep
and my sheep know me.'

Part of the process of laying down your life is to become known. It is
to open yourself up, becoming vulnerable, sharing your pain, weaknesses,
and sin. The laid down life is one were there are no masks, pretences or
performances, but honest openness. Knowing and being known are essential
if we are going to find God's appointed place for our lives.

'The reason why my Father loves me is that I lay down my life.'

It would be very easy to conclude from this verse that Jesus was
saying that he needed to earn his father's love by laying down his life.
We know from the scriptures that God's love cannot be bought or earned,
so how are we to understand these words?

Could it be that Jesus' willing sacrifice elicited the Father's
eternal love in a fresh way? For example, I have loved my wife for over
25 years. Now if she does something that reflects her love for me, which
would cause my love for her to well up in a fresh way so that I say, "I
love you for doing that for me." The love was there before her deed, but
her deed called forth my love once more.

I think Jesus is saying that when he laid down his life it did not
cause God to love his Son. But it caused the love God had for his Son to
to well up inside him. Maybe this is Jesus' way of saying that the laid
down life brings great joy and pleasure to God. The laying down of
Jesus' life for the sheep, is an act that expresses to the world, that
Jesus felt secure in his father's love. Because Jesus felt secure in his
father's love he was prepared to lay down his life and eventually die on
the cross.

The kind of 'laid down life' that God is looking for is only possible
when we are feeling secure in the love of God. Feelings of insecurity
will prevent a person from living a sacrificial laid down life, because
insecurity encourages and develops selfishness within a person. The more
we receive and enjoy God's love the more secure we will be, and the more
secure we are the more equipped we will be to lay down our lives.

The security Jesus felt, meant that he had the authority to lay down
his life. 'No one takes it from me but I lay it down of my own accord. I
have authority to lay it down and authority to take it up again.' This
is alluding to Jesus' death, but in this context it is primarily
referring to how Jesus lived. The word that John uses for authority
literally means 'unrestricted possibility or freedom of action.' In
other words Jesus was free enough to lay down his life.

When a person is free because they feel secure in the love of God,
they will be prepared to meet the demands and sacrifices that the
Christian life requires. We cannot live the life of a Christian without
a conscious knowledge of God's love. Knowledge of God's love is the most
effective sanctifying and freeing influence a person can experience.

In laying down his life for others Jesus was outworking the natural
consequences of obeying his Father's commandments. 'I have authority to
lay it down and authority to take it up again. This commandment I have
received from my father.'

In our western culture we have over individualised obedience, but
every time we obey the word of God, it is not solely for our own
individual and personal benefit, but it is also for the enrichment and
encouragement of others. Obedience to the commandments will equip a
person for his ordination, it will make a laid down life a reality.

With that in mind, let me mention our understanding of abundant that
Jesus refers to in verse 10. Abundant life is not an individualistic
experience; rather it is the result of feeling secure within the flock.
Abundant life is a relational quality that is discovered in the midst of
community. Abundant life is an impossible individual experience.
prayer:
Father, may my love for you be seen in me laying down my
life for others
